metadata.purpose: Provides instructions and a template for writing effective tutorials for the VTEX Developer Portal.
metadata.usage: A comprehensive and structured format for creating tutorials in the VTEX Developer Portal. Tutorials are learning-oriented, aiming to help readers understand concepts and perform a series of related tasks.

title.description: The title of the tutorial must include the product's name and reflect the learning objective.
title.validation_heuristic: Ensure the title is formatted as '<Tutorial title>', with the verb in the gerund form. The title must state the tutorial's goals.

slug.description: A unique identifier for the tutorial, generated by hyphenating the title in lowercase without special characters.

hidden.description: A boolean value indicating whether the tutorial is visible to the public or hidden (for draft or internal use).

createdAt.description: The date and time when the release note was created, typically in ISO 8601 format (e.g., '2025-04-25T10:00:00Z').

updatedAt.description: The date and time when the release note was last updated, typically in ISO 8601 format (e.g., '2025-04-25T10:00:00Z').

body.description: Start with an introduction that states the learning objective, explains the context, and outlines what the reader will learn.
Lists all necessary prerequisites the user must meet or complete before following the steps in the guide.

The steps will be presented as a list. The list is in the templates after the sentence 'Here's an overview of the parts'. Each step's title starts with a verb in the gerund form. Should guide the user from one point to the next in a logical sequence.
Summarize the main concepts learned, and suggest follow-up tutorials or resources for further learning.

rules.description: Use clear, direct language without unnecessary adverbs or marketing speak.
validation_heuristic: Flag unnecessary adverbs (e.g., 'simply', 'easily') in instructional content.

rules.validation_heuristic: Verify text avoids both overly casual language ('stuff', 'thing') and overly formal constructions ('one must', 'the user shall').

rules.description: The language should remain professional and clear.
rules.validation_heuristic: Verify text avoids the use of slang ('thing', 'tweak', 'config').

rules.description: Use second-person pronouns (e.g., 'you') to address the reader directly.
rules.validation_heuristic: Ensure the text uses 'you' or 'your' instead of third-person references (e.g., 'the user').

examples.correct: Use the `vtex setup` command to initialize your environment.
examples.incorrect: Simply run `vtex setup` to effortlessly bootstrap your stuff.
examples.explanation: Adding 'effortlessly'/'simply' in the incorrect version introduces unnecessary subjectivity and promotional tone. The correct version avoids this and stays factual.

examples.correct: Use the `vtex setup` command to initialize your environment.
examples.incorrect: Simply run the setup and you're good to go.
examples.explanation: The incorrect sentence is vague ('the setup'), uses imprecise language ('you're good to go'), and adds 'simply'â€”all of which reduce clarity. The correct version avoids this and stays factual.

examples.correct: You can configure your store settings directly in the Admin panel.
examples.incorrect: Just go to the Admin thing and tweak your config there.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version is too informal and uses slang ('Admin thing', 'tweak your config'). The correct version is professional and clear.

rules.description: Use active voice instead of passive voice.
rules.validation_heuristic: Check for passive constructions (e.g., 'The settings can be configured by the user') and rewrite in active voice (e.g., 'You can configure the settings').

rules.description: Use second-person pronouns (e.g., 'you') to address the reader directly.
rules.validation_heuristic: Ensure the text uses 'you' or 'your' instead of third-person references (e.g., 'the user').
Flag subjective terms that may not apply universally (e.g., 'easy', 'quick'). Replace with factual descriptions.

examples.correct: You can configure the settings in the Admin panel.
examples.incorrect: The settings can be configured in the Admin panel.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version uses passive voice, which is less direct. The correct version uses active voice for clarity.

examples.correct: You can access your account settings from the dashboard.
examples.incorrect: The user can access their account settings from the dashboard.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version uses third-person pronouns, which creates distance. The correct version addresses the reader directly.

examples.correct: The process takes approximately five minutes to complete.
examples.incorrect: The process is quick and easy to complete.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version uses subjective terms ('quick', 'easy'). The correct version provides a factual description.

rules.description: Always use the full feature or product name on first reference. Abbreviations may be used thereafter if they are clearly defined.
rules.validation_heuristic: Check if the first instance of a term is spelled out in full, followed by the abbreviation in parentheses (e.g., 'Order Management System (OMS)').

rules.description: Avoid abbreviations unless they are widely recognized (e.g., 'URL', 'API').
rules.validation_heuristic: Flag obscure abbreviations (e.g., 'config' for 'configuration') unless they are explicitly defined or industry-standard.

rules.description: Spell out acronyms on first use in a document or section, followed by the acronym in parentheses.
rules.validation_heuristic: Verify that the first occurrence of an acronym is expanded (e.g., 'Content Delivery Network (CDN)').

rules.description: Do not redefine acronyms if they are already spelled out elsewhere in the document or are globally recognized (e.g., 'HTML', 'PDF').
rules.validation_heuristic: Flag redundant expansions of common acronyms (e.g., 'HyperText Markup Language (HTML)').

rules.description: Avoid contractions in technical documentation (e.g., use 'do not' instead of 'don't').
rules.validation_heuristic: Flag contractions (e.g., 'can't', 'won't') and replace with full forms.

rules.description: Exceptions include UI labels or quoted text where contractions are part of the original material.
rules.validation_heuristic: Allow contractions only in direct quotes or UI reproductions (e.g., a button labeled 'Don't save').

examples.correct: First, enter the Order Management System (OMS). Then, click...
examples.incorrect: First, enter the OMS. Then, click...
examples.explanation: The incorrect version fails to define 'OMS' on first use. The correct version spells it out and introduces the abbreviation.

examples.correct: Configure the settings in the Admin panel.
examples.incorrect: Config the settings in the Admin panel.
examples.explanation: 'Config' is an informal abbreviation. The correct version uses the full term for clarity.

examples.correct: The Content Delivery Network (CDN) improves performance. The CDN caches static assets.
examples.incorrect: The CDN improves performance. The CDN caches static assets.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version assumes prior knowledge of 'CDN'. The correct version defines it upfront.

examples.correct: Export the report as a PDF.
examples.incorrect: Export the report as a Portable Document Format (PDF).
examples.explanation: 'PDF' is globally recognized and does not require expansion.

examples.correct: You cannot create a product without a brand.
examples.incorrect: You can't create a product without a brand.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version uses a contraction, which is less formal. The correct version uses the full form.

examples.correct: The UI displays the message: 'Don't save'.
examples.incorrect: The UI displays the message: 'Do not save'.
examples.explanation: The incorrect version alters the original UI text. Contractions are allowed in direct reproductions.
